question: Question 1 If [latex]v_1, v_2,..., v_6[/latex] are six vectors in [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex], which one of the following statements is False?
solution: [latex]v_1, v_2,..., v_6[/latex] are six vectors in [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex]. For a 4-dimensional vector space, (i) any four linearly independent vectors form a basis (or) (ii) Any set of four vectors in [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex] spans  [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex], then it forms a basis. Therefore, clearly options (A), (B), (D) are true. Option (C) is FALSE

options.A: It is not necessary that these vectors span [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex].
options.B: These vectors are not linearly independent.
options.C: Any four of these vectors form a basis for [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex].
options.D: If {[latex]v_1, v_3,v_5, v_6[/latex]} spans [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex], then it forms a basis for [latex]\mathbb{R}^4[/latex].

question: Question 2 For a vector field [latex]\vec{A}[/latex], which one of the following is False?
solution: Divergence and curl operator is performed on a vector field [latex]\vec{A}[/latex] Curl operation provides a vector orthogonal to the given vector field [latex] \vec{A} [/latex] [latex]\bigtriangledown \times(\bigtriangledown \times \vec{A})=\bigtriangledown (\bigtriangledown \cdot \vec{A})-\bigtriangledown ^2 \vec{A}[/latex] If a vector field is irrortational then  [latex]\bigtriangledown \times \vec{A}=0[/latex] If a vector field is solenoidal then [latex]\bigtriangledown \cdot \vec{A}=0[/latex] If a field is scalar A, then [latex]\bigtriangledown ^2  \vec{A}=0[/latex], is a laplacian equation. Hence option (C) is incorrect

question: Question 3 The partial derivative of the function [latex]f(x,y,z)=e^{1-x \cos y}+xze^{-1/(1+y^2)}[/latex] with respect to x at the point (1,0,e) is
solution:
[latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Given, } f(x,y,z)&=e^{1-x\cos y}+xze^{-1/(1+y^{2})} \\ \frac{\partial f}{\partial x}&=e^{1-x\cos y}(0-\cos y)+ze^{-1/1+y^{2}} \\ \left ( \frac{\partial f }{\partial x} \right )_{(1,0,e)}&=e^{0}(0-1)+e\cdot e^{-1/(1+0)} \\ &=-1+1=0
\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 4 The general solution of [latex]\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}-6\frac{dy}{dx}+9y=0[/latex] is
solution:
Taking [latex] \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} x}=D[/latex] Given, [latex]
  D^{2}-6D+9=0 [/latex] [latex]
(D-3)^2=0[/latex] [latex]
 D=3,3[/latex] So, Solution of the given Differential equation [latex]y=(C_{1}+C_{2}x)e^{3x}[/latex]

question: Question 5 The output y[n] of a discrete-time system for an input x[n] is [latex]y[n]=\begin{matrix} max\\ -\infty \leq k\leq n \end{matrix}\; |x[k]|[/latex]. The unit impulse response of the system is

Question 6 A single crystal intrinsic semiconductor is at a temperature of 300 K with effective density
of states for holes twice that of electrons. The thermal voltage is 26 mV. The intrinsic
Fermi level is shifted from mid-bandgap energy level by
solution: [latex]\frac{E_{c}+E_{v}}{2}-E_{F_{i}}=\frac{KT}{2}\ln \left ( \frac{N_{C}}{N_{V}}\right )\, \, \, \, \, \, \left ( \because N_{C}=\frac{N_{V}}{2} \right )[/latex] [latex]=\frac{0.026}{2}\ln 0.5=-9.01\, meV[/latex]

question:
Question 7 Consider the recombination process via bulk traps in a forward biased [latex]pn[/latex] homojunction
diode. The maximum recombination rate is [latex]U_{max}[/latex]. If the electron and the hole capture
cross-section are equal, which one of the following is False?

options.A:
With all other parameters unchanged, [latex]U_{max}[/latex] decreases if the intrinsic carrier density
is reduced.
options.B: [latex]U_{max}[/latex] occurs at the edges of the depletion region in the device.
options.C: [latex]U_{max}[/latex] depends exponentially on the applied bias.
options.D:
With all other parameters unchanged,[latex]U_{max}[/latex] increases if the thermal velocity of the
carriers increases.

question:
Question 8 The components in the circuit shown below are ideal. If the op-amp is in positive feedback
and the input voltage [latex]V_i[/latex] is a sine wave of amplitude 1 V, the output voltage [latex]V_o[/latex] is
solution:
Given circuit is a Schmitt trigger of non-inverting type. [latex]V_{o}=\pm 5\, V[/latex] [latex]V^{+}=\frac{V_{o}\times 1+V_{i}\times 1}{1+1}=\frac{V_{o}+V}{2}[/latex] let,[latex] V_{o}=-5\, V,\, \, \, \,V^{+}=\frac{-5+V_{i}}{2}[/latex] [latex]V_{o}[/latex] 
can change from -5 V to +5 V if [latex]V^{+} \gt 0 [/latex] i.e.  [latex]\frac{-5+V_{i}}{2} \gt 0\Rightarrow V_{i} \gt 5\, V[/latex] similarly, [latex]V_{o}[/latex] 
can change from -5 V to +5 V if [latex]V_{i} \lt -5\, V[/latex] But given input has peak value 1 V. Hence output cannot change from +5 V to -5 V or -5 V to +5 V. Output remain constant at +5 V or -5 V.

options.A: a non-inverted sine wave of 2 V amplitude
options.B: an inverted sine wave of 1 V amplitude
options.C: a square wave of 5 V amplitude

question: Question 9 In the circuit shown below, the Thevenin voltage [latex]V_{TH}[/latex] is
solution: By applying the Source Transformation

question:
Question 10 The figure below shows a multiplexer where [latex]S_1 \; and \; S_0[/latex] are the select lines, [latex]I_0 \; to \; I_3[/latex] are 
the input data lines, EN is the enable line, and [latex]F(P, Q, R)[/latex] is the output, F is
solution: Output,[latex]F=\bar{P}\bar{Q}R+P\bar{Q}R+PQ\, \, \, \,[/latex] [latex] F=\bar{Q}R+PQ[/latex]

question: Question 11 The pole-zero map of a rational function G(s) is shown below. When the closed counter [latex]\Gamma[/latex] is mapped into the G(s)-plane, then the mapping encircles.
solution: s-plane contour is encircling 2-poles and 3-zeros in clockwise direction hence the corresponding G(s) plane contour encircles origin 2-times in anti-clockwise direction and 3-times in clockwise direction. Therefore,  Effectively once in clockwise direction.

options.A: the origin of the G(s)-plane once in the counter-clockwise direction.
options.B: the origin of the G(s)-plane once in the clockwise direction.
options.C: the point -1+j0 of the G(s)-plane once in the counter-clockwise direction.
options.D: the point -1+j0 of the G(s)-plane once in the clockwise direction.

question:
Question 12 A digital communication system transmits a block of N bits. The probability of error in
decoding a bit is [latex]\alpha[/latex]. The error event of each bit is independent of the error events of
the other bits. The received block is declared erroneous if at least one of the its bits
is decoded wrongly. The probability that the received block is erroneous is
solution: Probability of error in decoding single bit=[latex]\alpha[/latex] Then probability of no error will be [latex]1- \alpha[/latex]. Total N-bits transmitted, so that probability of no error in received block =[latex](1-\alpha )(1-\alpha )...N \, \text{ Times}[/latex] [latex]=(1-\alpha) ^{N}[/latex] The Probability of received block is erroneous is [latex]=1-(1-\alpha) ^{N}[/latex]

question: Question 13 The impedances Z=jX, for all X in the range ([latex]-\infty ,\infty[/latex]), map to the Smith chart as
solution: For given impedance Normalized impedance is [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{Z}{Z_{0}}&=\frac{jX}{Z_{0}}\\ Z&=jX \\ \Rightarrow \; Z&=0+jX \end{aligned}[/latex] Normalized Resistance  [latex]=0 \; \Rightarrow \;  r=0[/latex] [latex]X=-\infty \text{ to } \infty[/latex] [latex]r=0[/latex] and X from [latex]-\infty \, to\, \infty[/latex] is a unit circle (radius 1) and centre (0,0) on a complex reflection coeffient plane:

options.A: a circle of radius 1 with centre at (0, 0).
options.B: a point at the centre of the chart.
options.C: a line passing through the centre of the chart
options.D: a circle of radius 0.5 with centre at (0.5, 0).

question:
Question 14 Which one of the following pole-zero corresponds to the transfer function of an LTI system
characterized by the input-output difference equation given below? [latex]y[n]=\sum_{k=0}^{3}(-1)^k x[n-k][/latex]

Question 15 In the given circuit, the two-port network has the impedance matrix[latex][Z] =\begin{bmatrix} 40 & 60\\ 60 & 120 \end{bmatrix}[/latex]. The value of [latex]Z_L[/latex] for which maximum power is transferred to the load is _________ [latex]\Omega[/latex].
solution: From maximum power transfer theorem [latex]Z_{L}=Z_{th} [/latex] [latex]Z_{th}=Z_{22}-\frac{Z_{12}\times Z_{21}}{R_{S}+Z_{11}}[/latex] For given data, [latex]Z_{th}=120-\frac{60\times 60}{10+40}=48\Omega[/latex] [latex] Z_{L}=48\Omega[/latex]

question:
Question 16 The current in the RL-circuit shown below is [latex]i(t) = 10cos(5t-\pi /4)A[/latex]. The value of the
inductor (rounded off to two decimal places) is _________ H.
solution: [latex]Z=\frac{V}{I}=\frac{200\angle 0^{\circ}}{10\angle -45^{\circ}}=20\angle 45^{\circ}[/latex] [latex]Z=10\sqrt{2}+j10\sqrt{2}[/latex] [latex]X_{L}=10\sqrt{2}[/latex] [latex]\omega L=10\sqrt{2}[/latex] [latex]L=\frac{10\sqrt{2}}{5}=2.828\, H[/latex]

question:
Question 17 In the circuit shown below, all the components are ideal and the input voltage is
sinusoidal. The magnitude of the steady-state output [latex]V_0[/latex] (rounded off to two decimal
places) is _________ V.
solution: Voltage Doubles, [latex]V_{o}=2\: V_{m}=2\times 230\sqrt{2}\cong 650.4V[/latex]

question:
Question 18 In the circuit shown below, all the components are ideal. If [latex]V_i[/latex] is +2 V, the current [latex]I_o[/latex] sourced
by the op-amp is __________ mA.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} V_o=(1+1) \times 2&=4V \\ \text{KCL at node } V_o & \\ \frac{2-4}{1k\Omega }I_o+\frac{0-4}{1k\Omega }&=0 \\ -2+I_o-4 &=0 \\ I_o&=6mA \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 19 In an 8085 microprocessor, the number of address lines required to access a 16 K byte
memory bank is __________.
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}2^{n}&=N  \\ 
n & \rightarrow \text{ Number of Address Lines} \\ N & \rightarrow \text{ Number of Memory Locations} \\ 2^{n}&=16 KB \\ &=2^{4} (2^{10}) \\ &=2^{14}\\ n&=14\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 20 A 10-bit D/A converter is calibrated over the full range from 0 to 10 V. If the input to
the D/A converter is 13A (in hex), the output (rounded off to three decimal places) is
_________ V.
solution: Given,  n=10 [latex]V_{FS}=10\, V[/latex] Input Voltage=[latex](13A)_{16}=(314)_{10}[/latex] Output Voltage=Resolution X Decimal Equivalent of input [latex]V_{o}=\frac{10}{2^{10}-1}\times 314=3.069\, V[/latex]

question:
Question 21 A transmission line of length [latex]3\lambda /4[/latex] and having a characteristic impedance of 50[latex]\Omega[/latex] is
terminated with a load of 400[latex]\Omega[/latex]. The impedance (rounded off to two decimal places)
seen at the input end of the transmission line is __________ [latex]\Omega[/latex].

Question 22 A binary random variable X takes the value +2 or -2. The probability [latex]P(X=+2)= \alpha[/latex].
The value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] (rounded off to one decimal place), for which the entropy of X is maximum,
is __________
solution:
Given that, [latex]P(X=2)=\alpha[/latex] Entropy Will be Maximum; Provided Probabilities are equal. i.e.   [latex] P(X=2)=P(X=-2)=\alpha =\frac{1}{2}[/latex] [latex]
\alpha =\frac{1}{2}=0.5[/latex]

question: Question 23 The loop transfer function of a negative feedback system is [latex]G(s)H(s)=\frac{K(s+11)}{s(s+2)(s+8)}[/latex] The value of K, for which the system is marginally stable, is ________.
solution: Characteristic equation q(s) for the given open loop system will be [latex]q(s)=s^{3}+10s^{2}+16s+Ks+11K=0[/latex] Using R-H criteria, For System to be Marginally Stable [latex]\begin{aligned}\frac{10(16+K)-11K}{10}&=0 \\ 160+10K-11K&=0 \\ K&=160\end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 24 The random variable [latex]Y=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t)\phi (t) dt[/latex] where [latex]\phi (t) =\left\{\begin{matrix} 1; & 5\leq t\leq 7\\ 0; & otherwise \end{matrix}\right.[/latex] and W(t) is a real white Gaussian noise process with two-sided power spectral density [latex]S_W(f) = 3[/latex] W/Hz, for all f. The variance of Y is _________.
solution: [latex] \begin{aligned} \text{Given:  }\phi (t) &=\left\{\begin{matrix} 1 & 5\leq t\leq 7\\ 0 & otherwise \end{matrix}\right. \\ s_{\omega }(f)& =3 \text{ Watts/Hz} \\ R_{\omega }(\tau )&=3\delta (\tau )=3\delta (t_{1}-t_{2})  \\ Var[y]&=E[y^{2}]-{E[y]}^{2} \\ {E[W(t)]}^{2}&=\text{DC  power} \\ &=\text{Area under PSD at }f=0  \\ {E[W(t)]}^{2}&=0  \\ E[W(t)]&=0 \\ y&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t)\phi (t)dt \\ E[y]&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }E[W(t)]\phi (t)dt \\ y&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t)\phi (t)dt\rightarrow E[y^{2}]\\ &=S_{\omega }(f)\cdot Energy[\phi (t)]\\ & =3 \times 2=6\\ \text{Var}[y]&=6-0=6\end{aligned}[/latex] Detailed Explanations for: [latex]\begin{aligned}y&=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t)\phi (t)dt \\ E(y^{2})&=E[y \cdot y] \\ &=E[\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t_{1})\phi (t_{1})dt_{1}\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t_{2})\phi (t_{2})dt_{2}] \\ &=E[\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }W(t_{1})W(t_{2})\phi (t_{1})\phi (t_{2})dt_{1}\cdot dt_{2}] \\ &=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }E[W(t_{1})W(t_{2}) \cdot \phi (t_{1})\phi (t_{2})dt_{1} dt_{2}] \\ &=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }R_{W}(t_{1}-t_{2})\phi (t_{1})\phi (t_{2})dt_{1}dt_{2} \\ &=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }3\delta (t_{1}-t_{2})\phi (t_{1})\phi (t_{2})dt_{1}dt_{2}\end{aligned}[/latex] Above Integration Exists Provided [latex]\begin{aligned}t_{1}&=t_{2}=t\\ &=\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }3\delta (0)\phi (t)\phi (t)dt \, dt\\ &=3 \int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \delta (0) dt + \int_{-\infty }^{\infty } \phi ^2 (t) dt\\&=2 \times 1 \times \text{Energy}[\phi (t)] \\E[y^{2}]&=6\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 25 The two sides of a fair coin are labelled as 0 and 1. The coin is tossed two times
independently. Let M and N denote the labels corresponding to the outcomes of those
tosses. For a random variable X, defined as X = min(M, N), the expected value E(X)
(rounded off to two decimal places) is _________.
solution: s={(H,H),(H,T),(T,H),(T,T)} [latex]M=\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 1 & 0 & 0 \\ H & H & T & T \end{bmatrix}[/latex] of first toss [latex]N=\begin{bmatrix} H & T & H& T \\ 1 & 0 & 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] of second toss Now,X=Min{M,N} [latex]\therefore[/latex] X=Min{H,H}=Min{1,1}=1 X=Min{H,T}=Min{1,0}=0 X=Min{T,H}=Min{0,1}=0 X=Min(T,T)=Min(0,0)=0 [latex]\therefore[/latex]P(X=1)=[latex]\frac{1}{4}[/latex],P(x=0)=[latex]\frac{3}{4}[/latex] We Know that, [latex]E(X)=\sum_{i}X_{i}P(x_{i})=1\times \frac{1}{4}+0\times \frac{3}{4}=\frac{1}{4}=0.25[/latex]

question: Question 26 Consider the following system of linear equation. [latex]x_1+2x_2=b_1;[/latex] [latex]2x_1+4x_2=b_2;[/latex] [latex]3x_1+7x_2=b_3;[/latex] [latex]3x_1+9x_2=b_4;[/latex] Which one of the following conditions ensures that a solution exists for the above system?
Question 27 Which one of the following options contains two solutions of the differential equation [latex]\frac{dy}{dx}=(y-1)x[/latex]?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \frac{dy}{dx}&=(y-1)x\\ \frac{dy}{y-1}&=x dx\\ \text{Integrating}&\text{ both side, we get}\\ \int \frac{1}{y-1}dy&=\int xdx\\ \ln |y-1|&=\frac{x^2}{2}+C\; \; \;...(i)\\ \text{Now, }&\\ \frac{dy}{dx}&=0 \text{ when y=1}\\ \text{It means }y&= \text{constant C}\\ \therefore \; y&=1\;\;\;...(ii) \end{aligned}[/latex] So, equation (i) and (ii) are two different solution of given differential equation.

question: Question 28 The current I in the given network is
solution: [latex]I=-[I_{1}+I_{2}][/latex] [latex] I=-\left [ \frac{120\angle -90^{\circ}}{80-j35}+\frac{120\angle -30^{\circ}}{80-j35} \right ] [/latex] [latex]I=2.38\angle 143.7^{\circ}[/latex]

question:
Question 29 A finite duration discrete-time signal x[n] is obtained by sampling the continuous-time
signal [latex]x(t) = \cos (200 \pi t)[/latex] at sampling instants t = n/400, n = 0,1,..., 7. The 8-point
discrete Fourier transform (DFT) of x[n] is defined as [latex]x[k]=\sum_{n=0}^{7}x[n]e^{-j\frac{\pi kn}{4}}[/latex],  k=0,1,...,7. Which one of the following statement is TRUE?
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}x(t)&=\cos 200\pi t\\ t&=\frac{n}{400}\\ x(n)&=\cos \left ( 200\pi \frac{n}{400} \right )\\&=\cos \left ( \frac{\pi }{2} n\right ); \; \; n=0,1,...,7\\ &=\left \{ \cos 0,\cos \frac{\pi }{2},\cos \pi ,\cos \frac{3\pi }{2} ,\cos 2\pi ,\cos \frac{5\pi }{2},\cos 3\pi ,\cos \frac{7\pi }{2}\right \} \\  &={1,0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0}\xLeftrightarrow{\text{DFT}} X(K) \\ \text{suppose, }  y(n)&={1,-1,1,-1}\xLeftrightarrow{\text{DFT}} Y(k)\end{aligned}[/latex] [latex][Y(K)]=\left.\begin{matrix} [W_{N}] \end{matrix}\right|_{N=4}[y(n)]=\begin{bmatrix} 1 &1 &1 &1 \\ 1 &-j &-1 &j \\ 1&-1 &1 &-1 \\ 1&j& -1 &-j \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} 1\\ -1\\ 1\\ -1 \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} 0 &0 &4 &0 \end{bmatrix}[/latex] Now,as we know, If for [latex]\, \left \{ a,b,c,d \right \}\xLeftrightarrow{\text{DFT}} \left \{ A,B,C,D \right \} [/latex] Then for, [latex]\left \{ a,0,b,0,c,0,d,0 \right \}\xLeftrightarrow{\text{DFT}}\left \{A,B,C,D,A,B,C,D \right \}[/latex] Similarly for [latex] y(n)={1,-1,1,-1}\xLeftrightarrow{\text{DFT}}Y(k)=\left \{ 0,0,4,0\right \}[/latex] Here, for [latex]x(n)=\left \{ 1,0,-1,0,1,0,-1,0 \right \} [/latex] [latex]X(k)=\left \{ \underset{0}{\uparrow},0,4,0,0,0,4,0 \right \}[/latex]

options.C: Only X[2] and X [6] are non-zero
options.D: Only X[3] and X [5] are non-zero

question: Question 30 For the given circuit, which one of the following is the correct state equation?
solution: From source transformation, KVL in loop 1, [latex]2i_{1}=2i+0.5\frac{\mathrm{d} i}{\mathrm{d} t}+V [/latex] [latex]\frac{\mathrm{d} i}{\mathrm{d} t}=-2V-4i+4i_{1}[/latex] KCL at node (a), [latex]i=0.25\frac{\mathrm{d} V}{\mathrm{d} t}+\frac{V-i_{2}}{1}[/latex] [latex] \frac{\mathrm{d} v}{\mathrm{d} t}=-4V+4i+4i_{2}[/latex] [latex] \begin{bmatrix} v\\ i \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} -4 & 4\\ -2 & -4 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} v\\ i \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix} 0 &4 \\ 4 &0 \end{bmatrix}\begin{bmatrix} i_{1}\\ i_{2} \end{bmatrix}[/latex]

question:
Question 31 A one-sided abrupt [latex]pn[/latex] junction diode has a depletion capacitance CD of 50 pF at a reverse
bias of 0.2 V. The plot of [latex]1/C_D^2[/latex] versus the applied voltage V for this diode is a straight
line as shown in the figure below. The slope of the plot is ____[latex]\times 10^{20} F^{-2} V^{-1}[/latex].
solution: As per GATE official answer key MTA (Marks to ALL) Depletion or transition capacitance is, [latex]C_{D}=\frac{A_{\epsilon }}{W}[/latex] For one-sided PN junction [latex]\left (EX:P^{+}N Junction \right )[/latex] [latex]W=\sqrt{\frac{2\epsilon V_{B}}{eN_{D}}}=\sqrt{\frac{2\epsilon \left ( V_{bi}-V \right )}{eN_{D}}}[/latex] where V is anode to cathode applied potential. [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, \, \, C_{D}=\frac{A\epsilon }{\sqrt{\frac{2\, \epsilon \left ( V_{bi}-V \right )}{eN_{D}}}} [/latex] [latex]\Rightarrow \, \, \, \, \frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=\frac{2}{A^{2}\epsilon eN_{D}}\left ( V_{bi}-V \right )[/latex] [latex] \frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}\, becomes \, zero \, at V=V_{bi}[/latex] From above graph,[latex]y=\frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=0\, at\, x_{1}=V_{bi}[/latex] [latex] And \, \, \, y_{2}=\frac{1}{C_{D}^{2}}=4\times 10^{20}\, at\, x_{2}=-0.2V [/latex] [latex]Slope=\frac{y_{2}-y_{1}}{x_{2}-X_{1}}=\frac{4\times 10^{20}-0}{-0.2-V_{bi}}[/latex] [latex] V_{bi}[/latex] is not provided,slope cannot be found.

question:
Question 32 The band diagram of a p-type semiconductor with a band-gap of 1 eV is shown. Using
this semiconductor, a MOS capacitor having [latex]V_{TH}[/latex] of [latex]-0.16 V, C'_{ox}[/latex] of 100 [latex]nF/cm^2[/latex] and
a metal work function of 3.87 eV is fabricated. There is no charge within the oxide. If
the voltage across the capacitor is [latex]V_{TH}[/latex]. the magnitude of depletion charge per unit area
(in [latex]C/cm^2[/latex]) is

Question 33 The base of an npn BJT T1 has a linear doping profile [latex]N_B(x)[/latex] as shown below. The base
of another npn BJT T2 has a uniform doping [latex]N_B[/latex] of [latex]10^{17} cm^{-3}[/latex]. All other parameters are
identical for both the devices. Assuming that the hole density profile is the same as
that of doping, the common-emitter current gain of T2 is
solution: As per GATE official answer key MTA (Marks to ALL) [latex]\frac{\beta _{1}}{\beta _{2}}=\frac{\int_{0}^{W}N_{A_{2}}(x)dx}{\int_{0}^{W}N_{A_{1}}(x)dx}=\frac{W\times 10^{17}}{\frac{1}{2}\times W\times (10^{17}-10^{14})}=\frac{2\times 10^{17}}{10^{17}+10^{14}}\simeq 2[/latex]

question:
Question 34 A pn junction solar cell of area 1.0 [latex]cm^{2}[/latex], illuminated uniformly with 100 mW [latex]cm^{-2}[/latex],
has the following parameters: Efficiency = 15%, open circuit voltage = 0.7 V, fill
factor = 0.8, and thickness = 200 [latex]\mu m[/latex], The charge of an electron is [latex]1.6 \times 10^{-19}[/latex]C. The
average optical generation rate (in [latex]cm^{-3} s^{-1}[/latex]) is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}\eta &=\frac{\left ( FF \right )V_{OC}I_{SC}}{P_{in}} \\ 0.15&=\frac{0.8\times 0.7\times I_{SC}}{100mW} \\ I_{SC}&=\frac{15}{0.56}mA \\ G_{L}&=\frac{I_{SC}}{q \times \text{ Area } \times \text{ thickness } } \\ &=\frac{15 \times 10^{-3}}{0.56 \times 1.6 \times 10^{-19} \times 1\times 200\times 10^{-4}} \\ &=\frac{15}{0.56\times 32}\times 10^{19}\\ &=0.837\times 10^{19} \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 35 For the BJT in the amplifier shown below, [latex]V_{BE} = 0.7 V, kT/q = 26 mV[/latex]. Assume the BJT
output resistance ([latex]r_o[/latex]) is very high and the base current is negligible. The capacitors are
also assumed to be short circuited at signal frequencies. The input [latex]v_i[/latex] is direct coupled.
The low frequency gain [latex]v_o/v_i[/latex] of the amplifier is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}I_{EQ}&=\frac{10-0.7}{20}=0.465mA\\ g_{m}&=\frac{I_{EQ}}{V_{T}}=\frac{0.465}{26}A/V \\ \frac{V_{out}}{V_{in}}&=-g_{m}(R_{e}\parallel R_{L})\\ &=\frac{0.465}{26}\times 5000=-89.423\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 36 An enhancement MOSFET of threshold voltage 3 V is being used in the sample and
hold circuit given below. Assume that the substrate of the MOS device is connected
to -10 V. If the input voltage [latex]V_I[/latex] lies between [latex]\pm 10[/latex] V, the minimum and the maximum
values of [latex]V_G[/latex]
required for proper sampling and holding respectively, are
solution: for holding MOSFET should be OFF. [latex]\begin{aligned}V_{1\, min}&\rightarrow -10\, V \\ V_{G}-V_{1\, min}& \lt 3 \\ V_{G}& \lt 3-10V\Rightarrow -7V \\ \text{For Sampling, } V_{G}-V_{i\, max}& \gt 3\\ V_{G}& \gt 3+V_{i\, max}\\ V_{G}&\gt 13\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 37 Using the incremental low frequency small-signal model of the MOS device, the Norton
equivalent resistance of the following circuit is
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}v_{\pi }&=-V_{x} \\ V_{x}&=\left ( I_{x}-g_{m}V_{x} \right )r_{ds}+I_{x}R\\ V_{x}\left ( 1+g_{m} r_{ds}\right )&=\left ( r_{ds}+R \right )I_{x} \\ R_{N}&=\frac{V_{x}}{I_{x}}=\frac{R+r_{ds}}{1+g_{m}r_{ds}}\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 38 P, Q, and R are the decimal integers corresponding to the 4-bit binary number 1100
considered in signed magnitude, 1's complement, and 2's complement representations,
respectively. The 6-bit 2's complement representation of (P+Q+R) is
solution: Given, binary number 1100 1's complement of 1100 = -3 Sign magnitude of 1100 = -4 2's complement of 1100 = -4 P + Q + R = -4 - 3 - 4 = -11 The 6 digit 2's complement of (-11) = 110101

question:
Question 39 The state diagram of a sequence detector is shown below. State  [latex]S_0[/latex] is the initial state
of the sequence detector. If the output is 1, then

Question 40 The characteristic equation of a system is [latex]s^3 + 3s^2 + (K + 2)s + 3K = 0[/latex] In the root locus plot for the given system, as K varies from 0 to [latex]\infty[/latex], the break-away
or break-in point(s) lie within
solution:
[latex]Q(s)=1+G(s)H(s)=0 [/latex] [latex]s^{3}+3s^{2}+2s+ks+3k=0 [/latex] [latex]-k=\frac{s^{3}+3s^{2}+2s}{s+3}[/latex] [latex] -\frac{\mathrm{d} k}{\mathrm{d} s}=\frac{(s+3)(3s^{2}+6s+2)-(s^{3}+3s^{2}+2s)}{(s+3)^{2}}=0[/latex] [latex] 3s^{3}+6s^{2}+2s+9s^{2}+18s+6-s^{3}-3s^{2}-2s=0[/latex] [latex] 2s^{3}+12s^{2}+18s+6=0[/latex] [latex] s=-0.46,-3.87,-1.65[/latex] [latex]\therefore[/latex]
Break-away point lies between (0, -1), i.e. (-1, 0)

question:
Question 41 The components in the circuit given below are ideal. If R = 2 [latex]k\Omega[/latex] and C = 1 [latex]\mu F[/latex], the
-3 dB cut-off frequency of the circuit in Hz is
solution: Op-amp active filter (LPF) inverting type 3 dB cut-off frequency, [latex]f_{c}=\frac{1}{2\pi RC}=\frac{1}{2\pi \times 2\times 10^{3}\times 10^{-6}}=\frac{500}{2\pi }=79.58Hz[/latex]

question:
Question 42 For the modulated signal [latex]x(t)= m(t) \cos(2 \pi f_c t)[/latex], the message signal [latex]m(t) = 4 \cos (1000 \pi t)[/latex] and the carrier frequency [latex]f_c[/latex] is 1 MHz. The signal [latex]x(t)[/latex] is passed
through a demodulator, as shown in the figure below. The output [latex]y(t)[/latex] of the
demodulator is
solution: Output of multiplier [latex]=x(t)\cos 2\pi (f_{c}+40)t=m(t)\cos 2\pi f_{c}t\cdot \cos2\pi (f_{c}+40)t[/latex] [latex] =\frac{m(t)}{2}[\cos 2\pi (2f_{c}+40)t+\cos 2\pi (40)t][/latex] Given, [latex]m(t)=4\cos 1000\pi t[/latex] So, output of multiplier [latex]=2\cos 2\pi (500)t[\cos 2\pi (2f_{c}+40)t+\cos 2\pi (40)t][/latex] [latex]=\cos 2\pi (2f_{c}+540)t+\cos 2\pi (2f_{c}-460)t+\cos 2\pi (540)t+\cos 2\pi (460)t[/latex] Output of Low pass filter [latex]=\cos [2\pi (460)]t[/latex] [latex] =\cos 920\pi t[/latex]

question:
Question 43 For an infinitesimally small dipole in free space, the electric field [latex]E_\theta[/latex] in the far field
is proportional to [latex](e^{-jkr}/r) \sin \theta[/latex], where [latex]k = 2 \pi /\lambda[/latex]. A vertical infinitesimally small
electric dipole ([latex]\delta l \lt \lt \lambda[/latex]) is placed at a distance [latex]h(h \gt 0)[/latex] above an infinite ideal
conducting plane, as shown in the figure. The minimum value of h, for which one
of the maxima in the far field radiation pattern occurs at [latex]\theta =60^{\circ}[/latex], is
solution:
[latex]\begin{aligned}\left | \text{Total E }\right |&=\left | (E_{\text{single element}}) \right | \left | (A.F.) \right | \\ \left | (A.F.) \right |&=\frac{\sin\left ( N\frac{\psi }{2} \right )}{\sin (\frac{\psi }{2})}=\frac{\sin \left ( 2\frac{\psi }{2} \right )}{\sin \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right )} \\ & =\frac{2\sin \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right )\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})}{\sin \frac{\psi }{2}} \\ & =2\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})\\  \left | A.F_{N} \right | &=\frac{A.F}{A.F_{max}}=\frac{2\cos (\frac{\psi }{2})}{2} \\ &=\left | \cos \left ( \frac{\psi }{2} \right ) \right | \\
\text{where, }\psi &=\beta d\cos \theta =\frac{2\pi }{\lambda }(2h)\cos \theta  \\ \left.\begin{matrix} \left | A.F_{N} \right |_{\theta =60^{\circ}} \end{matrix}\right|& =\left | \cos (\frac{2\pi }{\lambda }h\cos 60^{\circ}) \right |\\ &=\left | \cos \left ( \frac{\pi h}{\lambda } \right ) \right |\\ \cos \theta  \text{ is maximum ,where   } \theta &=n\pi \;\; n=0,1,2..\\ \frac{\pi h}{\lambda }&=n\pi \Rightarrow h=n\lambda \\ \Rightarrow \; \text{For } n=1,  \;\; h_{min}&=\lambda \end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 44 In the voltage regulator shown below, [latex]V_l[/latex] is the unregulated at 15 V. Assume [latex]V_{BE}[/latex]= 0.7 V
and the base current is negligible for both the BJTs. If the regulated output [latex]V_O[/latex] is 9 V,
the value of [latex]R_2[/latex] is ________ [latex]\Omega[/latex].
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}9\times \frac{R_{2}}{R_{2}+1K\Omega }&=4 \\ 9R_{2}&=4R_{2}+4K\Omega\\ 5R_{2}&=4K \\ R_{2}&=\frac{4000}{5}=800\Omega \end{aligned}[/latex]

question: Question 45 The magnetic field of a uniform plane wave in vacuum is given by [latex]\vec{H}(x,y,z,t)=(\hat{a}_x+2\hat{a}_y+b\hat{a}_z) \cos (\omega t+3x-y-z)[/latex] The value of b is _____
solution: For uniform plane wave [latex]\hat{a}_{H}\cdot \hat{a}_{\rho }=0[/latex] [latex]\hat{a}_{H}[/latex]is unit vector in magnetic field direction [latex]\hat{a}_{\rho }[/latex] is unit vector in power flow direction [latex]\hat{a}_{H }=\frac{1\hat{a}_{x}+2\hat{a}_{y}+b\hat{a}_{z}}{\sqrt{1^{2}+2^{2}+b^{2}}} [/latex] [latex]\hat{a}_{\rho }=\frac{-3\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}+\hat{a}_{z}}{\sqrt{3^{2}+1^{2}+1^{2}}}[/latex] [latex] \hat{a}_{H}\cdot \hat{a}_{\rho }=0 (\hat{a}_{x}+2\hat{a}_{y}+b\hat{a}_{z})\cdot (-3\hat{a}_{x}+\hat{a}_{y}+\hat{a}_{z})=0[/latex] [latex] -3+2+b=0[/latex] [latex] b=1[/latex]

question:
Question 46 For a 2-port network consisting of an ideal lossless transformer, the parameter [latex]S_{21}[/latex] (rounded
off to two decimal places) for a reference impedance of 10 [latex]\Omega[/latex], is _____.
solution: For ideal transformer of n : 1, the scattering matrix is [latex]\begin{bmatrix} S_{11} &S_{12} \\ S_{21} & S_{22} \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix} \frac{n^{2}-1}{n^{2}+1} &\frac{2n}{n6{}} \\ & \end{bmatrix}[/latex] [latex]S_{21}=\frac{2n}{n^{2}+1}=\frac{2(2)}{2^2+1}=\frac{4}{5}=0.8[/latex]

question:
Question 47 [latex]S_{PM}(t)\; and \; S_{FM}(t)[/latex] as defined below, are the phase modulated and the frequency modulated
waveforms, respectively, corresponding to the message signal m(t) shown in the figure. [latex]S_{PM}(t)= \cos (1000 \pi t+K_p m(t))[/latex] and [latex]S_{FM}(t)= \cos (1000 \pi t+K_f \int_{-\infty }^{t} m(\tau )d\tau )[/latex] where [latex]K_p[/latex] is the phase deviation constant in radians/volt and [latex]K_f[/latex] is the frequency deviation
constant in radians/second/volt. If the highest instantaneous frequencies of [latex]S_{PM}(t)\; and \; S_{FM}(t)[/latex] are same, then the value of the ratio  [latex]\frac{K_p}{K_f}[/latex] is ______ seconds.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned}S(t)_{pm}&=A_c \cos [2\pi f_{c}t+k_pm(t)]\\ S(t)_{Fm}&=A_c \cos [2\pi f_{c}t+k_{f}\int_{0}^{\infty }m(t)dt]\end{aligned}[/latex] Instantaneous frequency are equal [latex]\begin{aligned}f_{i}&=\frac{1}{2\pi }\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} t}\theta (t)\\f_{iPM}&=f_{c}+\frac{K_p}{2\pi }\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} t} m(t)\\ f_{iFM}&=f_{c}+\frac{K_f}{2\pi }m(t)\\ \text{Given that,  } (f_{iPM})_{max}&=(f_{iFM})_{max} \\ f_{c}+\frac{k_P}{2\pi}[\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} t}m(t)]_{max}&=f_{c}+\frac{K_{f}}{2\pi }[m(t)]_{max}\\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{k_P}{2\pi}\frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} t}m(t) \end{matrix}\right|_{max} &= \left. \begin{matrix}  \frac{K_{f}}{2\pi }[m(t)] \end{matrix}\right|_{max}\\ \left.\begin{matrix} \frac{\mathrm{d} }{\mathrm{d} t}m(t) \end{matrix}\right|_{max} &=5,  \left.\begin{matrix} m(t) \end{matrix}\right|_{max}=10 \\ 5k_{p}&=10k_{f} \\ \frac{k_{p}}{k_{f}}&=2\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 48 In a digital communication system, a symbol S randomly chosen from the set ([latex]s_1, s_2, s_3, s_4[/latex])
is transmitted. It is given that [latex]s_1=-3, s_2=-1, s_3=+1[/latex] and [latex]s_4=+2[/latex]. The received
symbol is Y = S + W. W is a zero-mean unit-variance Gaussian random variable and
is independent of S. [latex]P_i[/latex] is the conditional probability of symbol error for the maximum
likelihood (ML) decoding when the transmitted symbol [latex]S=s_i[/latex]. The index i for which the
conditional symbol error probability [latex]P_i[/latex] is the highest is ______.
solution:
Since the noise variable is Gaussian with zero mean and ML decoding is used, the
decision boundary between two adjacent signal points will be their arithmetic mean.
In the following graphs, the shaded area indicates the conditional probability of decoding
a symbol correctly when it is transmitted. By comparing the above graphs, we can conclude that [latex]P_{3}[/latex] is larger among the four.
End of Solution

question:
Question 49 A system with transfer function [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{(s+1)(s+a)}, a \gt 0[/latex] is subjected an input [latex]5\cos 3t[/latex].
The steady state output of the system is [latex]\frac{1}{\sqrt{10}} \cos (3t-1.892)[/latex]. The value of [latex]a[/latex] is ____.
solution: Given that, [latex]\begin{aligned}G(j\omega )&=\frac{1}{(1+j\omega )(\alpha +j\omega )} \\ \left |G(j\omega ) \right |&=\frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}} \\ \text{According to }& \text{question,}\\ \left | G(j\omega ) \right |_{\omega =3}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}}\\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{(\omega ^{2}+1)(\omega ^{2}+\alpha ^{2})}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \\ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{10(a^{2}+9)}}&=\frac{1}{5\sqrt{10}} \alpha ^{2}+9=25 \\ \alpha ^{2}&=16 \\ \alpha &=4\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 50 For the components in the sequential circuit shown below, [latex]t_{pd}[/latex] is the propagation delay, [latex]t_{setup}[/latex] is the setup time, and [latex]t_{hold}[/latex] is the hold time. The maximum clock frequency (rounded
off to the nearest integer), at which the given circuit can operate reliably, is ____ MHz.
solution: Total propagation delay  [latex]=(t_{pd}+t_{set-up})_{max}=8ns+5ns=13ns[/latex] [latex] \therefore[/latex] Frequency of operations [latex]=\frac{1000}{13}MHz=76.92MHz[/latex]

question:
Question 51 For the solid S shown below, the value of [latex]\int \int_S \int x dxdydz[/latex] (rounded off to two decimal
places) is ______.

Question 52 [latex]X(\omega )[/latex] is the Fourier transform of [latex]x(t)[/latex] shown below. The value of [latex]\int_{-\infty }^{\infty }|X(\omega )|^2 d\omega[/latex]  (rounded
off to two decimal places) is ______.
solution: [latex]\begin{aligned} \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\left | X(\omega ) \right |^{2}d\omega &=2\pi \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\left | x(t) \right |^{2}dt \\ &=2\pi \int_{-\infty }^{\infty }\left | y(t) \right |^{2}\\      &=2\times 2\pi \int_{-2}^{0}\left | y(t) \right |^{2}dt\\      &=2\times 2\pi\left [ \int_{-2}^{-1}(t+2)^{2}dt+\int_{-1}^{0}(2t+3)^{2}dt \right ]\\&=4\pi \left [\left \{ \frac{(t+2)^{3}}{3} \right \} _{-1}^{-2}+\left \{ \frac{(2t+3)^3}{3\times 2} \right \}_{0}^{-1} \right ]\\&=4\pi \left [ \frac{1-0}{3}+\frac{3^{3}-1}{6} \right ]\\&=4\pi \left [ \frac{1}{3}+\frac{26}{6} \right ]\\&=     4\pi \times \left [ \frac{1}{3}+\frac{26}{6} \right ] \\ &=4\pi \times \left [ \frac{1}{3}+\frac{13}{3} \right ]\\&=4\pi \times \frac{14}{3} \\&=\frac{56\pi }{3}=58.61\end{aligned} [/latex]

question:
Question 53 The transfer function of a stable discrete-time LTI system is [latex]H(z)=\frac{K(z-\alpha )}{z+0.5}[/latex], where K
and [latex]\alpha[/latex] are real numbers. The value of [latex]\alpha[/latex] (rounded off to one decimal place) with [latex]|\alpha| \gt 1[/latex],
for which the magnitude response of the system is constant over all frequencies, is _____.
solution: System is all-pass filter. For digital all-pass filter, condition is [latex]\text{zero}=\frac{1}{\text{pole}^{*}}\; \; ...(i)[/latex] By given transfer function, [latex]\text{zero}=\alpha [/latex] [latex] \text{Pole}=-0.5 [/latex] using condition(i), [latex] \alpha =\frac{1}{-0.5}=-2[/latex]

question: Question 54 X is a random variable with uniform probability density function in the interval [-2,10]. For Y = 2X-6, the conditional probability [latex]P(Y \leq 7|X \geq 5)[/latex] (rounded off to three decimal places) is _____.
solution: [latex]x[/latex] follows uniform distribution over [-2, 10] [latex]\begin{aligned} \therefore \; f(x)&=\frac{1}{b-a}=\frac{1}{10-(-2)}=\frac{1}{12}\\ \text{Given: } y &= 2x - 6\\ \Rightarrow \; x&=\frac{y+6}{2}\\ \text{For } y = 7 \\ x&=\frac{7+6}{2}=\frac{13}{2}=6.5\\ P\left [ \frac{y\lt7}{x\gt 5} \right ]&=P\left [ \frac{x\lt6.5}{x\gt 5} \right ] \\ &=\frac{P\left [ x\gt 5\, and\, x\lt6.5 \right ]}{P\left [ x\gt 5 \right ]} \\ &=\frac{P\left [ 5\lt x \lt 6.5 \right ]}{P[x\gt 5]} \\ &=\frac{\int_{5}^{6.5}f(x)dx}{\int_{5}^{10}F(x)dx} \\ &=\frac{\int_{5}^{6.5}\frac{1}{12}dx}{\int_{5}^{10}\frac{1}{12}dx} \\ &=\frac{(x)_{6.5}^{5}}{(x)_{5}^{10}}=\frac{1.5}{5}=0.3\end{aligned}[/latex]

question:
Question 55 Consider the following closed loop control system where [latex]G(s)=\frac{1}{s(s+1)}[/latex] and [latex]C(s)=K\frac{s+1}{s+3}[/latex].
If the steady state error for a unit ramp input
is 0.1, then the value of K is _______.
solution: Open loop transfer function for the system [latex]=C(s)\times G(s)=\frac{K(s+1)}{ (s+3)}\times \frac{1}{s(s+1)}[/latex] Since the system is type-1, so far a given unit ramp input steady state [latex]e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K_{V}} [/latex] where,  [latex]K_{V}=\lim_{s\rightarrow 0}S\times \frac{K}{S(S+3)}=\frac{K}{3} [/latex] so, [latex]\; e_{ss}=\frac{1}{K/3}=\frac{3}{K}[/latex] Given that,  [latex]\; e_{ss}=0.1 [/latex] So, [latex]0.1=\frac{3}{K}\Rightarrow K=30[/latex]
